citation.article-title: Halorhabdus utahensis gen. nov., sp. nov., an aerobic, extremely halophilic member of the Archaea from Great Salt Lake, Utah.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Halorhabdus utahensis sp. nov.
Halorhabdus utahensis (u'tah.ensis. M.L. n. pertaining to the state of Utah, USA, where the strain was isolated)
The description of Halorhabdus utahensis is identical to that given above for the genus, with the following additions.
The following substrates (0.2%, w/v) are utilized for growth: glucose, xylose and fructose.

No growth on amylose, arginine, D-arabinose, D-galactose, lactose, maltose, sucrose, Na-acetate, Na-citrate, Na-formiate, Na-D-glucuronate, Na-lactate, Na-pyruvate, N-acetyl-glucosamine, L-alanine, betaine, L-lysine, phenylalanine, L-proline, L-serine, acetamide, ethanol, glycerol, methanol, D-sorbitol, glycogen, peptone, yeast extract, starch, casein, gelatin or Tween 80.
No hydrolysis of gelatin or starch.
Does not produce protease or urease.
Does not produce arginine dihydrolase, lysine decarboxylase, ornithine decarboxylase or tryptophan deaminase.
The G+­C content of the DNA of the only strain known in the species is 64 mol%.

The type strain, strain AX-2T, isolated from Great Salt Lake, UT, USA, has been deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen und Zellkulturen GmbH (Braunschweig, Germany) as strain DSM 12940T.
